results.title: Fair play
results.creator_credit: Edmund Penney, Jack Wipper and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: The film encourages judgements on three situations which occur in play. The experiences of the playground are important social lessons. Sharing, kindness and responsibility for each other’s well being are some of the elements of “fair play”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edmund Penney, Jack Wipper and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: Fair play
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australian women cricketers are the undisputed world-cup cricket champions in a sport which is hotly contested by nine affiliated countries. This film follows their latest tour to England to play on the hallowed grounds at Lords.

results.title: Fair dinkum in Russia
results.brief_description: Footage of what appears to be an amateur documentary by a member of the Australian Shooting Team that took part in the 37th World Shooting Championships in Moscow, 1958. No production details available. Silent film.

results.title: Failing to learn, learning to fail (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Mike Gavin, Films Incorporated and National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: Investigates the relationship between learning disabilities and delinquent behaviour by examining the history of four youngsters afflicted with minimal brain dysfunction. Points out the importance of early diagnosis and reports on the progress being made in the treatment of this disorder.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Gavin, Films Incorporated and National Broadcasting Company

results.title: Fail safe
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Max Youngstein and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: A tense and suspenseful peice of filmmaking dealing with the frightening implications of accidental nuclear warfare. It faithfully translates to the screen the power and seething drama of the Eugene Burdick-Harvey Wheeler book of the same name. What if a computer malfunction was to set off events possibly resulting in a nuclear war? This is the basic premise of the gripping narrative that is realistically and almost frighteningly told as the US attempts to halt the plane carrying the bombs which has been sent to deploy its deadly cargo on the Russians when America’s complex defence system mistakes an off-course airliner for a hostile enemy plane and the sophisticated fail-safe device malfunctions. As time runs out and a global holocaust seems imminent, the President (Henry Fonda) is faced with implementing an appalling peace offering. It would be an interesting exercise to compare this film with “Dr. Strangelove” as both films deal with the same premise, which led to claims of plagiarism when “Failsafe” was originally released.

results.title: Fahrenheit 9/11
results.creator_credit: Michael Moore, Kathleen Glynn, Jim Czarnecki, Lions Gate Films, The Fellowship Adventure Group, IFC Productions (US) and Dog Eat Dog Films
results.brief_description: The heat is up in this award-winning documentary made by maverick dissident Michael Moore (“Bowling for Columbine”) with his sharp wit and biting commentary on the United States’ Government and contemporary America. President George W. Bush bares the brunt of this filmmaker’s wrath as Moore, with his sense of humour intact, sets about to make clear to the world American foreign policy and its consequences. This is the sort of filmmaking that gets people thinking, talking and hopefully, taking action. Not only did “Fahrenheit 9/11” win awards but its popularity with the cinema-going public created a record at the box office for a documentary film and paved the way for other works in the genre to be more prominent in the cinema exhibition market. Winner of Best Picture at Cannes 2004.

results.title: Fahrenheit 451
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, Lewis M. Allen and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Truffaut’s first English language film, and his first film shot in colour, is a visually elegant science fiction story about a future in which television dominates people’s lives and where books are forbidden. Montag (Oskar Werner) burns books for a living. He and his wife Linda live in an opulent suburban house where she takes pills to calm her while she interacts with the giant TV screen on her wall. Montag is bored but unaware of the nature of his alienation until he meets a radical schoolteacher on a train. Soon he picks up a forbidden book and begins reading. Under-rated on its original release, the film now impresses with a visually experimental colour palette and stark futurist sets which imaginatively represent the landscape of a technological fascism. Based on Ray Bradbury’s chilling novel, which itself was influenced by the book-burnings of totalitarianism, the film version now seems prophetic of our contemporary world where telecommunications are changing the nature of our immediate, physical interaction with the world. Julie Christie impresses in a difficult duel performance as Linda and as the schoolteacher.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

results.title: Fade to black
results.creator_credit: Vernon Zimmerman, Ron Hamady, George G. Braunstein, Movie Ventures and Leisure Investment
results.brief_description: Eric Binford (Dennis Christopher) is a movie freak, whose love of old movies goes way beyond the norm. He works at a film distributor’s warehouse, lives with his obsessive and controlling aunt Stella (Eve Brent Ashe) and spends most of his spare time watching late-night movies in his movie poster and memorabilia adorned bedroom. Eric lives in a fantasy world of his own, acting out his favourite characters and reciting well-known and well-worn one-liners to all and sundry. This obsession eventually takes a bizarre turn after he has a brief encounter with a Marilyn Monroe look alike (Australian born Linda Kerridge) who embodies all of his cinematic desires, but who also stands him up on their first potential date. Angry and disappointed, Eric snaps, his unbalanced and disturbed mind transforming him into a homicidal psychotic who becomes obsessed in seeking revenge on those who have taunted or oppressed him. Disguising himself in various classic movie characters including Dracula, The Mummy and Norman Bates, Eric embarks on a killing spree, reliving scenes from his favourite horror movies. This slasher/psychothriller cliche-filled film has its moments of humor, creepiness and horror but it lacks in script and direction and some unimpressive acting by the support cast. Special mention must be made, however, of a brief appearance by a very young Mickey Rourke. Cast also includes Tim Thomerson, Gwynne Gilford, Normann Burton, Morgan Paull, James Luisi.

results.title: Facts about projection
results.creator_credit: Robert Edmonds, Wesley Greene and John Ott Pictures
results.brief_description: Explains how a projectionist can put on a professional 16mm sound film screening by observing a check list of hints and safeguards. Emphasises the importance of a pre-showing check of the kind and source of power, light control facilities and ventilation; of the correct set-up of projector, speaker and screen; placement and plugging of cords; adjustment of focus, screen size, tone and volume controls and a final check for clean aperture before threading.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Edmonds, Wesley Greene and John Ott Pictures
